Candidatus Arsenophonus nilaparvatae is a recently discovered, uncultured bacterial endosymbiont associated with the brown planthopper, Nilaparvata lugens, an important agricultural pest. This species belongs to the Arsenophonus clade, a group of maternally inherited bacterial symbionts found in various insect hosts.

The genome of Candidatus Arsenophonus nilaparvatae has been partially sequenced, revealing that it is a Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium with a small genome size, typical of obligate intracellular symbionts. Phylogenetic analyses have shown that it is closely related to other Arsenophonus species found in other insect hosts, suggesting a shared evolutionary history and potential functional roles within their respective host organisms.

The exact nature of the relationship between Candidatus Arsenophonus nilaparvatae and its host, the brown planthopper, is still under investigation. However, studies have suggested that this endosymbiont may play a role in the insect's fitness, potentially affecting its host's reproduction, development, or ability to adapt to different environmental conditions. Further research is needed to elucidate the specific mechanisms and implications of this symbiotic association.
